facts.text: Writ Petition No. 87 of 1962 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 87 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Eight petitioners challenge validity of section 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: by which the eight petitioners challenged the validity of section 87B of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Petitioners and respondent No. 2, His Highness Maharaja Kirit Vikram Kishore Deb Varman, are members of a joint Hindu family governed by the Dayabhaga School of Hindu Law.

anchor.surface_text: These petitioners claim that they and respondent No. 2, His Highness Maharaja Kirit Vikram Kishore Deb Varman, are members off a joint Hindu family governed by the Dayabhaga School of Hindu Law.

facts.text: Family custom prevailed for centuries where Raj and Zamindari properties held by single individual, other members entitled to maintenance and succession rights.

anchor.surface_text: Under a family custom which, it is alleged, has prevailed in this family for centuries, the Raj as well as the Zamindari properties belonging to the family are held by a single individual and the other members of the family are entitled to maintenance according to the status of the family with the right to succession to the Raj as well as the Zamindari properties under the general rule of succession which prevails and which is number inconsistent with the family custom.

facts.text: Head of family called the Chief, chosen from Ruling Deb Barman family and installed on Gaddi or Throne.

anchor.surface_text: The head of the family was, by family custom, called the Chief and he was chosen from among the members of the Ruling Deb Barman family and used to be installed on the Gaddi or Throne.

facts.text: Ruler holds State and Zamindari as life tenant subject to maintenance charges for Ruling Family.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners further alleged that the Ruler when so chosen and installed held the State and Zamindari as life tenant subject to the usual charges for maintenance of the members of the Ruling Family.

facts.text: Maintenance allowances fixed arbitrarily by Rulers without regard to status and needs, leading to discontent and agitation during lifetime of late Maharaja Bir Bikram.

anchor.surface_text: In companyrse of time, the maintenance allowance of the members of the Ruling family came to be fixed arbitrarily by the Rulers without any regard to their status and their legiti- mate needs, and that led to discontent among them which re- sulted in a serious agitation raised by them during the lifetime of the late Maharaja Bir Bikram.

facts.text: Committee appointed on 20th June 1949 during Regency of Her Highness Rajmata for minority of Maharaja Kirit Bikram to consider allowances.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, at the time of Regency of Her Highness Rajmata during the minority of the last Ruler Maharaja Kirit Bikram, a Committee was appointed on the 20th June, 1949, to companysider the question of allowances payable to the members of the Ruling family.

facts.text: State of Tripura merged with India and constituted into separate Province under Chief Commissioner before Committee submitted report.

anchor.surface_text: However, before the Committee companyld submit its report, the State of Tripura merged with and became part of India and was companystituted into a separate Province under the Chief Commissioner.

facts.text: Chief Commissioner Mr. Hazra submitted proposal on 12th April 1951 recommending revision of allowances.

anchor.surface_text: After merger, the then Chief Commissioner Mr. Hazra submitted a proposal to the Ministry of States on the 12th April, 1951, recommending a revision of allowance paid to the maintenance-holders.

facts.text: Ministry of States refused increase on 23rd May 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The ministry of States did number accept this proposal and refused to make any increase in the total expenditure on the allowances to the maintenance-holders. This order was passed on the 23rd May, 1951.

facts.text: Officiating Chief Commissioner Maj. Chatterjee stopped maintenance allowances to some holders without justification.

anchor.surface_text: Later, the then ,officiating Chief Commissioner Maj. Chatterjee stopped the maintenance allowances paid to some of the maintenance,holders without justification

facts.text: Another Committee appointed but could not function, worsening condition of maintenance-holders.

anchor.surface_text: and that led to the appointment of another Committee to go into the matter, but the Committee companyld never function with the result that the companydition of the majority of the maintenance-holders grew worse day by day.

facts.text: Present eight petitioners desire to file suit against respondent No. 2 for appropriate reliefs, impleading Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: That is why the present eight petitioners desire to file a suit against respondent No. 2 for appropriate reliefs. They -want to implead the Union of India also to that suit,

facts.text: Petitioners required to obtain sanction of Union Government under s.87B CPC before filing suit against respondent No. 2, a Ruler of former Indian State.

anchor.surface_text: because it is their case that either the Ruler or the Union of India is responsible to pay them appropriate and adequate maintenance allowance. Before filing a suit in a companypetent companyrt of law against respondent No. 2, the petitioners are required to obtain the sanction of the Union Government under s. 87B C.P.C., as respondent No. 2 is a Ruler of a former Indian State within ,the meaning of the said section.

facts.text: Request for sanction by petitioners rejected by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: A request made by the petitioners for such sanction was rejected by the Central Government.

facts.text: Writ petition filed challenging validity of s.87B as ultra vires Arts.14 and 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: That is how the present petition has been filed challening the validity of the said section. The petitioners companytend that the said section is ultra vires, because it companytravenes Arts. 14 and 19 1  f  of the Constitution

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 6, 1964 by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J.

anchor.surface_text: March 6, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR C. J.-This is a writ petition filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitioner conceded at hearing that Art.14 challenge repelled by Mohan Lal Jain v. His Highness Maharaja Shri Sawai Man Singhji (1962 1 SCR 702).

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this writ petition, Mr. Shukla for the petitioners fairly companyceded that the challenge to the validity of s. 87B, C.P.C., on the ground that it companytravenes Art. 14 has been repelled by a recent decision of this Court in Mohan Lal Jain v. His Highness Maharaja Shri Sawai Man Singhji 1

facts.text: Court refused to reconsider Art.14 challenge based on Mohan Lal Jain case.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, attempted to argue that some aspects of the problem had number been pressed before the Court when it decided the case of Mohan Lal Jain 1 , and so, he wanted us to reconsider that question. We have number allowed Mr. Shukla to raise this companytention, because we are satisfied that the decision in Mohan Lal Jains case companycludes the point

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 is a Ruler of a former Indian State within meaning of s.87B(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to refer to these provisions, because it is companymon ground that respondent No. 2 is a Ruler of a former Indian State within the meaning of s. 87B 2

facts.text: Central Government refused sanction for petitioners' intended suit.

anchor.surface_text: It is this requirement which the petitioners have number been able to companyply with in respect of the suit which they intend to file against respondent No. 2, because the Central Government has refused to accord sanction to the said intended suit.

facts.text: Court upheld validity of s.87B against Art.19(1)(f) challenge.

anchor.surface_text: Considered in the light of this background, it is difficult to see how the petitioners can successfully challenge the validity of the provisions companytained in s. 87B.

facts.text: Writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: However, since it is number possible to accede to the petitioners argument that s. 87B is invalid, we see numberalternative but to dismiss the writ petition.

holdings.text: The challenge to the validity of s. 87B, C.P.C., on the ground that it contravenes Art. 14 stands repelled by the decision in Mohan Lal Jain v. His Highness Maharaja Shri Sawai Man Singhji and concludes the point such that reconsideration is not permitted.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this writ petition, Mr. Shukla for the petitioners fairly conceded that the challenge to the validity of s. 87B, C.P.C., on the ground that it contravenes Art. 14 has been repelled by a recent decision of this Court in Mohan Lal Jain v. His Highness Maharaja Shri Sawai Man Singhji 1 He, however, attempted to argue that some aspects of the problem had not been pressed before the Court when it decided the case of Mohan Lal Jain 1 , and so, he wanted us to reconsider that question. We have not allowed Mr. Shukla to raise this contention, because we are satisfied that the decision in Mohan Lal Jains case concludes the point

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioners conceded point; court holds prior Supreme Court decision binding and refuses reconsideration as it fully concludes the issue.

holdings.text: Ex-Rulers of Indian States form a class by themselves; special treatment under s.87B not based on unconstitutional discrimination under Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Mohan Lal Jain this Court has held that the ex-Rulers of Indian States form a class by themselves and the special treatment given to them by the impugned provisions cannot be said to be based on unconstitutional discrimination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts and applies holding from Mohan Lal Jain that ex-Rulers are homogeneous class justified by history.

holdings.text: The restriction imposed by s.87B on the fundamental right under Art.19(1)(f) is reasonable and in the interests of the general public.

anchor.surface_text: There is, of course, discrimination between the ex-Rulers and the rest of the citizens of India, but that discrimination is justified having regard to the historical and legislative background to which we have just referred. If that be so, it would follow that the restriction imposed on the petitioners fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(f) cannot be said to be unreasonable. The restriction in question is the result of the necessity to treat the agreements entered into between the Central Government and the ex-Rulers of Indian, States as valid and the desirability, of giving effect to the assurances given to them during the course of negotiations between the Indian States and the Central Government prior to the merger of the States with India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical covenants, merger necessities, legislative continuity under Art.372, and assurances under Art.362 justify discrimination and render restriction reasonable/proportional.

holdings.text: Section 87B CPC is constitutionally valid and does not contravene Arts.14 or 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: Considered in the light of this background, it is difficult to see how the petitioners can successfully challenge the validity of the provisions contained in s. 87B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines Art.14 class justification with reasonableness under Art.19 given background.

anchor.surface_text: However, since it is not possible to accede to the petitioners argument that s. 87B is invalid, we see no alternative but to dismiss the writ petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from upholding validity of s.87B.

holdings.text: It is advisable for Central Government to ordinarily grant sanction under s.87B for genuine disputes against former Rulers.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Advisory observation to prevent stifling genuine claims and reduce discontent; based on equality principles.

The factual requirement of obtaining sanction under s.87B CPC before filing suit against a Ruler of former Indian State directly triggers the provisions of Section 86 CPC dealing with suits against rulers and its extension to former Indian rulers.
The fact of sanction requirement under s.87B CPC in the petitioners' suit triggers the constitutional issue of whether s.87B contravenes Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Mohan Lal Jain this Court has held that the ex-Rulers of Indian States form a class by themselves and the special treatment given to them by the impugned provisions cannot be said to be based on unconstitutional discrimination.

In the case of Mohan Lal Jain this Court has held that the ex-Rulers of Indian States form a class by themselves and the special treatment given to them by the impugned provisions cannot be said to be based on unconstitutional discrimination.

By finding the s.87B restriction reasonable and in public interest, h3 supports the sanction requirement under c7.
Holding h3 that restriction is reasonable supports holding h4 that s.87B is valid and does not contravene Art.19(1)(f)

edges.explanation: Holding h3 addresses reasonableness of s.87B restriction under Art.19(1)(f), matching issue i2

anchor.surface_text: There is, of course, discrimination between the ex-Rulers and the rest of the citizens of India, but that discrimination is justified having regard to the historical and legislative background to which we have just referred. If that be so, it would follow that the restriction imposed on the petitioners fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(f) cannot be said to be unreasonable. The restriction in question is the result of the necessity to treat the agreements entered into between the Central Government and the ex-Rulers of Indian, States as valid and the desirability, of giving effect to the assurances given to them during the course of negotiations between the Indian States and the Central Government prior to the merger of the States with India.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 directly states Section 87B CPC is constitutionally valid, supporting the concept
By upholding s.87B CPC as constitutionally valid, h4 supports the concept c7 of Section 86 CPC and its application to former rulers.
The broad constitutional validity of s.87B in h4 (including non-contravention of Art.19(1)(f)) supports the specific reasonableness finding under Art.19(1)(f) in h3.

anchor.surface_text: Considered in the light of this background, it is difficult to see how the petitioners can successfully challenge the validity of the provisions contained in s. 87B.
However, since it is not possible to accede to the petitioners argument that s. 87B is invalid, we see no alternative but to dismiss the writ petition.

edges.explanation: Issue i2 explicitly questions whether section 87B CPC contravenes Article 19(1)(f), directly addressing the concept

Issue i2 on whether s.87B contravenes Art.19(1)(f) is directly addressed by holding h4 stating it does not contravene Art.19(1)(f)
